M.G.L. c. 208 \u00a7 28.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208 § 28, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody judgment if “a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment is no longer in the best interests of the child.”

M.G.L. c. 209C \u00a7 20.proposition: Similarly, pursuant to M.G.L. c. 209C § 20, custody and parenting orders concerning children of unmarried parents may be modified “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the child may require.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that a change in a parent’s health or capacity to care for a child may constitute a material change in circumstances.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody decision focused on the impact of domestic violence and the need for explicit findings about that issue. It does not discuss modification standards, material change in circumstances, or changes in a parent’s health or caregiving capacity as constituting a material change. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that changes in a parent’s health or capacity to care for a child can be a material change in circumstances.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below “fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.” ... Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have repeatedly held that a change in a parent’s health or capacity to care for a child may constitute a material change in circumstances.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what constitutes a “material and substantial change in circumstances” for custody modification but does not treat a change in a parent’s health or caregiving capacity as such a change. Instead, it finds no post-divorce change of sufficient magnitude to warrant modification and emphasizes that the mother’s work schedule had improved and did not justify changing custody. The case therefore does not affirm that changes in a parent’s health or caregiving capacity may constitute a material change; it essentially rejects the asserted changes as a basis for modification here.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle … whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ … We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1.proposition: The court’s paramount consideration is always the best interests of the child.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that in custody matters, the governing principle is the welfare of the child, describing it as the “dominating rule” that must guide the court. It affirms that the happiness and welfare of the child are the controlling consideration over parental wishes, and upholds the custody decision on that basis. This directly supports the proposition that the court’s paramount consideration is always the best interests of the child.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … ‘[T]he happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Care and Protection of Jeremy, 419 Mass..raw_text: Care and Protection of Jeremy, 419 Mass. 616 (1995)
Care and Protection of Jeremy, 419 Mass..proposition: These authorities collectively confirm that material changes—such as a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health—can justify reopening and adjusting custodial arrangements to protect a child’s welfare.
Care and Protection of Jeremy, 419 Mass..support_reasoning: The case does not address reopening or adjusting custodial arrangements based on a material change in a parent’s physical or mental health. Instead, it concerns whether a juvenile court judge may order a specific residential placement for a child in the Department of Social Services’ temporary custody and holds that such placement decisions rest with the department absent arbitrariness or abuse of discretion. There is no discussion of modifying custody due to parental deterioration or similar material changes in circumstances.
Care and Protection of Jeremy, 419 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “As the single justice noted, when a parent challenges the department’s manner of carrying out its custodial responsibility, in a case involving an order of temporary custody, § 21 authorizes a judge to ‘review’ the department’s decision. ‘The word “review” requires, in the context of judicial consideration of an administrative decision, a reexamination of an agency’s actions, and not a de novo consideration of the merits of the parties’ positions.’ Care & Protection of Isaac, supra at 610. Review, in these cases, is for legal error or abuse of discretion.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: These authorities collectively confirm that material changes—such as a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health—can justify reopening and adjusting custodial arrangements to protect a child’s welfare.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with relocation and modification in a joint physical custody context and discusses the best‑interests standard and relocation as a substantial change in circumstances, but it does not address parental deterioration in physical or mental health as a basis to reopen or adjust custody. The cited ALI Principles passage speaks of relocation constituting a substantial change, not health-related changes. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition that a parent’s deteriorating health can justify reopening and adjusting custodial arrangements.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise…
… (4)(c) If neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility for the child, the court should modify the plan… in accordance with the child’s best interests, taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.’”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: These authorities collectively confirm that material changes—such as a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health—can justify reopening and adjusting custodial arrangements to protect a child’s welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case concerns an initial divorce judgment awarding custody and permitting the custodial parent to remove the children to Greece; it does not involve a post-judgment modification based on a material change in circumstances such as a parent’s physical or mental health deterioration. The opinion does not discuss standards for reopening or adjusting existing custodial arrangements due to changed parental health conditions. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that material changes, including deterioration of a parent’s health, justify reopening and altering custody to protect a child’s welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)…”

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.proposition: These authorities collectively confirm that material changes—such as a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health—can justify reopening and adjusting custodial arrangements to protect a child’s welfare.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosen v. Rosen deals with child support arrearages, retroactive modification limits under G.L. c. 119A, § 13(a), and the narrow availability of equitable credits when a child moves to live with the payor parent. It does not address custody modification standards, material changes in circumstances, or a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health as a basis to reopen or adjust custodial arrangements. Thus it does not support the proposition about health-related material changes justifying changes in custody.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Consistent with the views of other jurisdictions, we conclude that a judge is not foreclosed by G. L. c. 119A, § 13(a), from determining whether ‘compelling circumstances of an equitable nature’ warrant the allowance of a credit for the payor’s fulfillment of his or her child support obligation ‘in a manner other than as directed by the original order’ but which nevertheless accomplishes the maintenance of the child as envisioned by the original order.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: These authorities collectively confirm that material changes—such as a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health—can justify reopening and adjusting custodial arrangements to protect a child’s welfare.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion applies the existing ‘best interests of the child’ standard to decide an initial custody allocation between two legal parents and discusses factors like stability, willingness to foster the other parent’s relationship, and geographic distance. It does not address modification of an existing custody or parenting plan based on later-arising, material changes such as a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health, nor does it discuss reopening or adjusting prior custodial arrangements on that basis. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about material changes justifying reopening custody orders.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child” ….’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: These authorities collectively confirm that material changes—such as a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health—can justify reopening and adjusting custodial arrangements to protect a child’s welfare.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The case concerns modification of alimony and child support based on an alleged material change in the payor’s financial circumstances, not modification of custody or visitation due to a parent’s physical or mental health deterioration. The opinion repeatedly frames the standard as a “material change of circumstances” but applies it solely to income, assets, employment, and second-family expenses; it does not discuss parental health or custodial arrangements. Thus it cannot be cited as authority that deterioration in a parent’s physical or mental health justifies reopening and adjusting custody to protect a child’s welfare.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered in a request for reduction of a support reward.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: These authorities collectively confirm that material changes—such as a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health—can justify reopening and adjusting custodial arrangements to protect a child’s welfare.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with initial custody determinations and visitation in the context of a divorce, not with modification or reopening of an existing custody order based on a material change in circumstances. There is no discussion of a parent’s subsequent deterioration in physical or mental health as grounds to revisit or adjust custodial arrangements. The cited passages about emotional health appear only to explain that comparative emotional health is one of many factors in an original best-interests analysis, not a basis for later modification.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does not claim that such ‘irrational’ fears of the wife could cause her to become a ‘nonfunctional’ parent and thus render her unfit… A determination that the wife was unfit for this reason alone would be dubious as ‘the comparative emotional health of the parents is only one of several factors which can affect the well being of their children.’ Angelone v. Angelone, 9 Mass. App. Ct. at 730.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: These authorities collectively confirm that material changes—such as a parent’s deterioration in physical or mental health—can justify reopening and adjusting custodial arrangements to protect a child’s welfare.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial custodial determination between unmarried parents and a dispute over whether the ‘best interests’ or ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard applies; it does not deal with reopening or modifying an existing custody order based on material changes like deterioration in a parent’s physical or mental health. The brief discussion of modification under G. L. c. 209C, § 20 is purely procedural and the court expressly declines to apply or analyze the modification standard on the merits. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the proposition that material health changes justify reopening and adjusting custody arrangements.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}
